content.text: State what is meant by _gravitational field strength_
Explain why, at the surface of a planet, gravitational field strength is numerically equal to the acceleration of free fall
An isolated uniform spherical planet has radius \(R\)
The acceleration of free fall at the surface of the planet is \(g\)
On Fig. 1.1, sketch a graph to show the variation of the acceleration of free fall with distance \(x\) from the centre of the planet for values of \(x\) in the range \(x = R\) to \(x = 4R\)
Fig. 1.1
The planet in **(b)** has radius \(R\) equal to \(3.4 \times 10^{3} \text{km}\) and mean density \(4.0 \times 10^{3} \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\)
Calculate the acceleration of free fall at a height \(R\) above its surface
acceleration of free fall =   .........  \(\text{m s}^{-2}\)
State what is meant by an _ideal gas_
Determine, to three significant figures, the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of the atoms of the gas
The temperature of the gas in the cylinder is \(22^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Determine, to three significant figures,
1. the amount, in mol, of the gas,
amount =   .........  mol
2. the mass of one atom of the gas
An ideal gas comprised of single atoms is contained in a cylinder and has a volume of \(1.84 \times 10^{-2} \text{m}^3\) at a pressure of \(2.12 \times 10^7 \text{Pa}\)
The mass of gas in the cylinder is \(3.20 \text{kg}\)
Use your answer in (b)(ii) part 2 to determine the nucleon number \(A\) of an atom of the gas

2. thermal energy is gained from the surroundings

content.text: The specific latent heat of fusion of ice is \(332 \text{J} \text{g}^{-1}\)
Show that the liquid column undergoes simple harmonic motion
The variation with time \(t\) of the displacement \(\mathbf{x}\) is shown in Fig. 4.3
Use data from Fig. 4.3 to determine the length \(L\) of the liquid column
Suggest one cause of this damping
Calculate the ratio
total energy of oscillations after 1.5 complete oscillations
total initial energy of oscillations
The oscillations shown in Fig. 4.3 are damped

Fig. 4.2

The liquid in the U-tube then oscillates such that its acceleration \(a\) is given by the expression
where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall
In radio communication, the radio wave is usually modulated
State what is meant by _amplitude modulation_ (AM)
determine the wavelength,
wavelength =   .........  m
describe the amplitude variation,
state the bandwidth
bandwidth =   .........  Hz
A sinusoidal radio carrier wave has a frequency of \(900\mathrm{kHz}\) and an unmodulated amplitude measured to be \(4.0\mathrm{V}\)
The carrier wave is amplitude modulated by a signal of frequency \(5.0\mathrm{kHz}\)
For the amplitude modulated wave,
State two other features, apart from the period, of a geostationary orbit
Suggest why
1. frequencies of the order of gigahertz are used for satellite communication,
Communication is sometimes made using satellites in geostationary orbits that have a period of rotation about the Earth of 24 hours
what is meant by the electric potential at a point,
the relationship between electric potential at a point and electric field strength at the point
State
Two similar solid metal spheres A and B, each of radius \(R\), are situated in a vacuum such that the separation of their centres is \(D\), as shown in Fig. 6.1
The charge \(+Q\) on sphere A is larger than the charge \(+q\) on sphere B
A movable point P is located on the line joining the centres of the two spheres
The point P is a distance x from the centre of sphere A
The output potential \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) of the op-amp circuit changes sign when the temperature of the thermistor is \(4.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Calculate the resistance \(R\)
R =   .........  \(\mathrm{k}\Omega\)
State and explain whether the output potential \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) is \(+5.0 \text{V}\) or \(-5.0 \text{V}\) for a thermistor temperature of \(2.5^{\circ} \text{C}\)
The output of the op-amp is to be displayed using two light-emitting diodes (LEDs) labelled G and B

When the temperature of the thermistor is below \(4.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), only the LED labelled G emits light. The LED labelled B emits light only when the temperature of the thermistor is above \(4.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
On Fig. 7.1, draw and label the symbols for the two LEDs
A circuit incorporating an ideal operational amplifier (op-amp) is shown in Fig. 7.1
The variation with temperature \(\theta\) of the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the thermistor is shown in Fig. 7.2
Define _magnetic flux density_
Explain why, when the current is switched on, the current in the sections PQ and RS of the wire does not affect the balance of the wire
The length of section QR of the wire is \(1.2 \text{cm}\)
Calculate the magnetic flux density \(B\)
A stiff copper wire is balanced horizontally on a pivot, as shown in Fig. 8.1
Sections PQ, QR and RS of the wire are situated in a uniform magnetic field of flux density \(B\) produced between the poles of a permanent magnet
The perpendicular distance of PQRS from the pivot is 7.5 cm
When a current of 2.7A is passed through the wire, a small mass of \(45 \text{mg}\) is placed a distance 8.8 cm from the pivot in order to restore the balance of the wire, as shown in Fig. 8.2
A Hall probe is placed near one end of a solenoid that has been wound on a soft-iron core, as shown in Fig. 9.1
The current in the solenoid is switched on
The Hall probe is rotated until the reading \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) on the voltmeter is maximum
The current in the solenoid is then varied, causing the magnetic flux density to change
The variation with time \(t\) of the magnetic flux density \(B\) at the Hall probe is shown in Fig. 9.2
At time \(t = 0\), the Hall voltage is \(V_0\)
On Fig. 9.3, draw a line to show the variation with time \(t\) of the Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) for time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = t_4\)
The Hall probe in **(a)** is now replaced by a small coil of wire connected to a sensitive voltmeter, as shown in Fig. 9.4
The magnetic flux density, normal to the plane of the small coil, is again varied as shown in Fig. 9.2
On Fig. 9.5, draw a line to show the variation with time \(t\) of the e.m.f. \(E\) induced in the small coil for time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = t_4\)
The root-mean-square (r.m.s.) value of the voltage of a sinusoidal alternating supply is \(9.9 \text{V}\). The frequency of the supply is \(50 \text{Hz}\)
Derive an expression for the variation with time \(t\) (in second) of the potential difference \(V\) (in volt) of the supply

The bone is \(0.40 \text{cm}\) thick and the total thickness of the bone and the soft tissue is \(1.8 \text{cm}\). The intensity of the transmitted beam is \(I\)
Data for the linear attenuation (absorption) coefficient \(\mu\) of bone and of soft tissue are given in Fig. 10.2
